0: Flat above shops alight - one casualty - PHOTOS NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR CM7 1JP, High Street, Braintree, NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 11/02/2015 @ 19:31 NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Incident Number: 31391 NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In attendance: 2 x Braintree, 2 x Halstead, 1 x Wethersfield, 2 x Chelmsford (aerial ladder platform), 1 x Basildon (Incident Command Unit) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A man clambered out of a window onto the top of a bus to escape a blaze in his flat above Ben's Cafe. When they arrived at the scene, firefighters pitched a ladder to reach him and bring him to safety. The casualty, believed to be in his forties, was treated by Ambulance Service paramedics after breathing in smoke. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Initially two appliances were sent to the scene but on arrival, the incident commander requested the attendance of an additional two appliances and an aerial ladder platform. At the height of firefighting operations, six appliances and an aerial ladder platform were at the scene. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Crews arriving at the incident reported that the first floor and roof of the three-storey flat were well alight and the first floor heavily smoke logged. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At 20:47 hrs, the incident commander reported steady progress in bringing the blaze under control. Firefighters in breathing apparatus were using two hose reels, two jets and an aerial ladder platform as they worked to extinguish flames. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At 21:12 hrs, firefighters reported that the fire was surrounded and steady progress was being made in extinguishing flames. Two jets, two hose reels and the aerial ladder platform were still in use as operations continued. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A fire investigation officer has been called to the scene to establish the cause of the blaze. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At 22:30 hrs, crews were still at the scene with the blaze under control. Three jets and three hose reels were being used to fight the fire. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Assistant Divisional Officer Dave Barritt, incident commander, said: “The man was trapped on the third floor and there was no way he could get out. If the bus hadn’t been there I don’t know how he would have escaped, the fall could easily have killed him. The bus driver’s actions saved this man’s life. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “It’s an unusual rescue, but it was extremely effective.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The incident was dealt with by 03:15 hrs. A joint Police and Fire Service investigation will be carried out to establish the cause. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The bus driver has been named as Andy Waterman. He is set to receive a commendation from Acting Chief Fire Officer Adam Eckley. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR First Bus in Essex have issued the following statement: NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A bus driver from Essex has been hailed a hero after he helped to rescue a man following a flat fire. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Eight fire crews were called to a flat fire above a shop in Braintree High Street Road at around 1930hrs on Wednesday, February 11. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Andy Waterman, a driver for First Essex, was driving the out of service bus back to First’s Braintree depot at the end of his shift when a group of people alerted him to the blaze. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Andy, who lives in West Mersea, positioned his double decker bus close to the roof of the flat, allowing the man to jump to safety. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said: “A group of people started flagging me down and they were asking me to stop. I asked them what the problem was and they said a man was stuck on the roof of his flat because it was on fire. I drove nearer and all I could see was thick, black smoke. I saw the man and thought ‘We’ve got to get him to safety’.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Andy positioned the bus as close to the flat as possible, while making sure he didn’t endanger himself or anyone else. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The man jumped around 10 ft onto the roof of the bus and Andy slowly drove away. The fire brigade then rescued the man from the roof of the bus. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Andy added: “The police told me that I did a good job. It wasn’t until I got home that someone said that I had saved a life. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I have been driving buses for eight years and nothing like this has happened before. I am just pleased the man is alive.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Adrian Jones, Managing Director for First Essex, praised Andy’s actions. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said: “We are very proud of Andy – he was in the right place at the right time. We are pleased to hear the man is ok and we wish him a quick recovery.” NEWLINE_CHAR First x shops of Essex and to depot NEWLINE_CHAR to scene a third continued. of ladder fire the two continued.
